title: What is Genetic Counseling?
description: Understanding the role of genetic counselors and what to expect from genetic counseling services

level1.title: Genetic Counseling: Your Guide to Understanding Your Genes
level1.content: Genetic counseling is a service that helps you understand how genes affect your health and your family's health. A genetic counselor is a specially trained healthcare professional who can explain genetic tests and help you make informed decisions about testing.

level2.title: Understanding Genetic Counseling Services
level2.content: Genetic counseling is a healthcare service that combines genetic education with emotional support. Genetic counselors are graduate-level trained professionals who help individuals and families understand genetic conditions, interpret test results, and navigate complex healthcare decisions related to hereditary health risks.

level3.title: The Science and Practice of Genetic Counseling
level3.content: Genetic counseling integrates clinical genetics, psychosocial assessment, and patient education to help individuals understand their genetic risk factors. Board-certified genetic counselors (CGCs) complete master's-level training and certification through the American Board of Genetic Counseling (ABGC), enabling them to interpret complex genetic information and guide patients through risk assessment, testing options, and informed decision-making.

level4.title: Advanced Concepts in Genetic Counseling Practice
level4.content: Modern genetic counseling encompasses comprehensive risk assessment using validated models (e.g., BRCAPRO, Tyrer-Cuzick, PREMM5), interpretation of multi-gene panel results, coordination of cascade testing in families, and facilitation of shared decision-making. Counselors integrate principles of non-directiveness with evidence-based recommendations while addressing the psychological, ethical, and social implications of genetic information.

level5.title: Precision Medicine and the Evolution of Genetic Counseling
level5.content: Contemporary genetic counseling operates at the intersection of precision medicine, behavioral genomics, and health policy. The field addresses challenges including variant reclassification, polygenic risk score interpretation, incidental and secondary findings management, and the integration of pharmacogenomics into clinical care. Advanced practice involves understanding penetrance variability, phenotypic heterogeneity, and the limitations of current risk models while navigating the evolving landscape of genetic discrimination protections and direct-to-consumer testing.

roleOfGeneticCounselor.title: The Role of a Genetic Counselor

level1.content: A genetic counselor helps you understand genetic conditions and testing. They explain things in simple terms, answer your questions, and support you through the process. They do not tell you what to do but help you make decisions that are right for you and your family.
keyPoints: Explains genetic conditions in simple terms
Helps you understand test options
Supports you emotionally
Answers your questions
Helps you make your own decisions

level2.content: Genetic counselors are healthcare professionals who specialize in medical genetics and counseling. Their role includes taking detailed family health histories, assessing genetic risks, explaining inheritance patterns, coordinating genetic testing, interpreting results, and providing emotional support. They work in hospitals, clinics, laboratories, and through telehealth services.
keyPoints: Collect and analyze family health history
Assess risk for genetic conditions
Explain how conditions are inherited
Coordinate and order genetic tests
Interpret and explain test results
Provide emotional support and resources
Connect families with support groups and specialists

level3.content: Genetic counselors function as integral members of the healthcare team, bridging clinical genetics expertise with patient-centered care. Their scope includes pre-test counseling with informed consent, pedigree construction and analysis, Mendelian and complex inheritance risk calculations, test selection and coordination, variant interpretation review, post-test counseling, and psychosocial assessment. They facilitate communication between patients, families, and healthcare providers while ensuring adherence to professional ethics and practice guidelines.
keyPoints: Construct and analyze multi-generational pedigrees
Calculate empiric and Mendelian risk estimates
Facilitate informed consent for genetic testing
Review and explain variant classifications
Coordinate care with multidisciplinary teams
Conduct psychosocial assessments
Advocate for patients in healthcare systems
Maintain confidentiality and manage family dynamics

level4.content: The genetic counselor's role encompasses comprehensive genetic risk assessment using evidence-based models, variant curation review in accordance with ACMG/AMP guidelines, and integration of genetic findings into medical management. They address the psychological impact of genetic information, facilitate family communication strategies, and navigate ethical dilemmas including incidental findings, testing of minors, and reproductive decision-making. Advanced roles include research, laboratory variant curation, and specialty practice in oncology, prenatal, pediatric, or cardiovascular genetics.
keyPoints: Apply validated risk assessment models (BRCAPRO, MMRpro, etc.)
Interpret variants using ACMG/AMP classification criteria
Develop personalized medical management recommendations
Address anticipatory guidance and surveillance protocols
Navigate ethical complexities in genetic testing
Facilitate cascade testing and family communication
Integrate findings with clinical specialists
Contribute to research and quality improvement initiatives

level5.content: Contemporary genetic counselors operate within a precision medicine framework, integrating germline and somatic testing results, polygenic risk scores, and pharmacogenomic data into personalized care plans. They navigate the challenges of variant reclassification, recontacting obligations, and the limitations of current evidence. Specialty practice requires expertise in phenotype-genotype correlations, modifier genes, and expressivity variability. The profession addresses health equity, genetic discrimination, and the responsible integration of direct-to-consumer and at-home testing into clinical care.
keyPoints: Integrate multi-omic data into clinical recommendations
Manage variant reclassification and patient recontact protocols
Address penetrance, expressivity, and genetic modifiers
Navigate direct-to-consumer testing integration
Advocate for health equity in genetic services
Contribute to professional policy and guideline development
Balance technological advances with ethical practice
Address social and systemic barriers to genetic services

level1.content: You might want to see a genetic counselor if you have concerns about conditions that run in your family, are planning a pregnancy, are pregnant and want to learn about testing options, or if you or a family member has been diagnosed with a genetic condition.
keyPoints: Family history of genetic conditions
Planning a pregnancy
Currently pregnant
Personal diagnosis of a genetic condition
Family member diagnosed with a genetic condition
Concerns about passing conditions to children
referralReasons: Conditions that seem to run in families

level2.content: Genetic counseling referrals are appropriate in multiple clinical scenarios. Prenatal indications include advanced maternal age, abnormal screening results, family history of genetic conditions, or exposure to teratogens. Cancer genetics referrals include multiple affected family members, early-onset cancers, or rare cancer types. Pediatric referrals may involve developmental delays, dysmorphic features, or suspected metabolic conditions. Adult referrals include personal or family history of hereditary conditions, preconception planning, or pharmacogenomic considerations.
keyPoints: Prenatal: advanced maternal age, abnormal screens, family history
Cancer: multiple affected relatives, early onset, bilateral tumors
Pediatric: developmental delays, dysmorphic features, failure to thrive
Cardiovascular: family history of sudden cardiac death, cardiomyopathy
Neurologic: movement disorders, early-onset dementia family history
Preconception: carrier screening, known family variants
Pharmacogenomics: adverse drug reactions, medication optimization

level3.content: Evidence-based referral guidelines have been established by professional organizations including ACMG, ACOG, NCCN, and specialty societies. Cancer genetics referral criteria include NCCN guidelines for hereditary cancer syndromes based on personal and family history. Prenatal referral criteria include ACOG recommendations for aneuploidy screening, carrier screening, and diagnostic testing. Cardiovascular genetics referrals are indicated for suspected channelopathies, cardiomyopathies, or familial hypercholesterolemia. Appropriate referral ensures timely access to risk assessment, testing, and management.

cancerGenetics: Ovarian/fallopian tube/primary peritoneal cancer any age
≥3 relatives with breast, ovarian, pancreatic, or prostate cancer
Colorectal or endometrial cancer <50 years or with family history

level4.content: Systematic referral pathways integrate clinical decision support tools, electronic health record alerts, and pedigree-based risk calculators to identify patients meeting guideline-based criteria. Quality metrics for genetic counseling services include time from referral to appointment, pre-test counseling completion rates, variant detection rates, and patient satisfaction. Barriers to appropriate referral include provider awareness gaps, geographic access limitations, and insurance coverage variability. Telegenetics and hybrid care models expand access while maintaining counseling quality.
keyPoints: Implement EHR-based clinical decision support for referral
Utilize validated risk calculators (Tyrer-Cuzick, PREMM5, etc.)
Address referral barriers through telegenetics
Monitor quality metrics for genetic services
Ensure timely access to genetic counseling
Coordinate with primary care for appropriate referrals
Develop institutional referral pathways and protocols

level5.content: Population-based approaches to genetic counseling are emerging, including universal carrier screening programs, population genomic screening initiatives (e.g., All of Us), and cascade testing programs for high-penetrance conditions. Implementation science frameworks guide the development of sustainable genetic service delivery models. Health economic analyses inform coverage decisions and resource allocation. Challenges include the expanding scope of actionable genetic findings, workforce capacity limitations, and the need for equitable access across diverse populations.
keyPoints: Develop population-based genetic screening programs
Apply implementation science to genetic service delivery
Address workforce capacity and training needs
Ensure health equity in genetic services access
Integrate genetic counseling into primary care models
Navigate expanding scope of actionable genetic findings
Contribute to health policy and coverage decisions

whatToExpect.title: What to Expect During Genetic Counseling

level1.content: During your appointment, the genetic counselor will ask about your health and your family's health. They will explain any conditions you are concerned about and discuss whether genetic testing might be helpful. The appointment usually lasts 30-60 minutes. You can bring a family member for support.
sessionComponents: Discussion of your concerns and goals
preparationTips: Gather information about family health history

level2.content: A typical genetic counseling session includes intake and rapport building, detailed family history collection with pedigree construction, risk assessment, education about relevant genetic conditions, discussion of testing options with informed consent, and development of a follow-up plan. Pre-test counseling addresses the benefits, limitations, and implications of testing. Post-test counseling includes result disclosure, interpretation, and management recommendations. Sessions may be conducted in-person or via telehealth.
sessionComponents: Genetic condition education with visual aids
Testing options discussion and informed consent
preparationTips: Gather medical records and prior test results
Research insurance coverage for genetic testing
Prepare list of questions and concerns
Consider family members' testing and results
Plan for emotional support during and after session

level3.content: Genetic counseling employs evidence-based counseling frameworks including motivational interviewing, shared decision-making, and recipient-centered counseling. Sessions integrate psychoeducation, risk communication using multiple formats (frequencies, percentages, visual aids), and assessment of patient understanding through teach-back methods. Documentation includes detailed pedigree analysis, risk calculations, informed consent elements, and recommendations. Quality indicators include patient knowledge gain, decision quality, and psychosocial outcomes.
sessionComponents: Comprehensive pedigree with medical documentation verification
Informed consent with documentation of understanding
Shared decision-making for testing and management

level4.content: Advanced genetic counseling sessions address complex scenarios including multi-gene panel result interpretation, variant of uncertain significance management, discordant family testing results, and integration of genetic findings with clinical phenotype. Counselors employ motivational interviewing techniques to address ambivalence and facilitate behavior change for recommended surveillance. Documentation supports billing, quality monitoring, and continuity of care. Outcomes research informs practice improvement and demonstrates value of genetic counseling services.
sessionComponents: Complex risk assessment using multiple models
Behavior change counseling for surveillance adherence

level5.content: Contemporary genetic counseling practice integrates advances in genomic medicine including whole exome/genome sequencing interpretation, somatic-germline integration in oncology, polygenic risk score counseling, and pharmacogenomic implementation. Sessions may address research participation, biobanking consent, and return of incidental/secondary findings. The field advances through outcomes research demonstrating the clinical utility and cost-effectiveness of genetic counseling, informing health policy and reimbursement. Competency-based training ensures practice keeps pace with rapidly evolving technology.
advancedConsiderations: Secondary findings disclosure per ACMG recommendations
Polygenic risk score integration and communication
Cultural competency and health literacy adaptation
Contribution to health services research and policy

level1.content: Your family health history is like a puzzle that helps show your risk for certain conditions. Knowing what conditions have affected your relatives helps your healthcare team understand what you might need to watch for. Try to learn about the health of your parents, siblings, grandparents, aunts, uncles, and cousins.
keyInformation: Cause of death for deceased relatives
Any known genetic test results in family
tips: Look at family records and documents
Create a family tree with health information

level2.content: A comprehensive family history includes a three-generation pedigree documenting health conditions, ages at diagnosis, and causes of death. This information enables risk stratification for hereditary conditions and guides testing recommendations. Key elements include cancer diagnoses with types, ages, and laterality; cardiovascular events; birth defects; developmental delays; and pregnancy losses. Documentation of ethnicity informs carrier screening recommendations based on population-specific risks.
pedigreeElements: Three generations minimum (parents, siblings, children, grandparents, aunts/uncles, cousins)
All cancer diagnoses with type, age, and bilateral/multiple primary status
Cardiovascular disease including age at onset
Neurological conditions and age at onset
Known genetic test results in family

level3.content: Systematic family history collection using validated tools (e.g., Surgeon General's My Family Health Portrait) improves completeness and clinical utility. Pedigree analysis identifies inheritance patterns (autosomal dominant, recessive, X-linked, mitochondrial) and red flags for hereditary syndromes. Risk calculation tools integrate family history data to generate quantitative risk estimates. Medical record verification of key diagnoses improves accuracy, as self-reported family history has known limitations in specificity.
redFlagsForHereditary: Multiple affected relatives with same/related cancers
Early age at diagnosis (before typical age)
Multiple primary cancers in same individual
Rare tumor types (e.g., male breast cancer, ovarian cancer)
limitations: De novo mutations have no family history

level4.content: Advanced pedigree analysis incorporates phenotypic details that inform testing strategies, including tumor histology, biomarkers, and treatment response. Integration with electronic health records enables systematic family history collection and clinical decision support alerts. Challenges include incomplete penetrance, variable expressivity, and phenocopies that complicate pattern recognition. Understanding founder mutations and population genetics informs ancestry-specific risk assessment and variant interpretation.
advancedElements: Tumor histology and biomarker status (ER, HER2, MSI, etc.)

level5.content: Precision family history integrates phenotypic data with genomic findings, including segregation analysis for variant interpretation, penetrance estimation from family data, and identification of genetic modifiers. Population-based initiatives aim to enhance family history collection at scale while addressing privacy and data sharing considerations. Emerging tools incorporate machine learning for pattern recognition and risk prediction, while research advances understanding of gene-environment interactions that modify hereditary risk.
advancedConsiderations: Modifier gene and polygenic background effects
